Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Phase I: iPerform - I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies to Enhance Human Performance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies (AT) will attract support for the advancement of AT research and promote innovation in academia that is driven by industrial needs. In work environments, ATs can improve work efficiency, identify safety risks, shorten the learning curve or worker training through simulations, and improve resource allocation, creativity and communication. In healthcare environments, AT tools can enhance sensory and cognitive capabilities, improve training & delivery, enable remote monitoring, delay physical and cognitive decline in chronic conditions, personalize rehabilitation, predict risks for the elderly who live alone, monitor sleep disorders, design better prosthetics or drugs, design better robotic assistants, smart wheelchairs, therapy games and tools to monitor mental/physiological conditions, such as depression, epilepsy, or heart problems. The seed projects conducted within the center will help advance basic research in computer vision, machine learning, user interfaces, brain imaging, human robot interaction, human computer interaction, virtual reality, simulation, and many other related research areas.

The projects conducted at I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies will drive a broad spectrum of advances in the areas such as worker productivity and safety, transportation, health, company operations and intelligence, and promote the development of AT research infrastructure. The center addresses real-world problems and thus can generate new jobs, products, services, and impact all areas where a human has the potential to improve. The center will play role in enhancing the quality and diversity of AT professionals and prepare a future generation of competitive employees-scientists who can solve problems due to unmet human needs. Through compelling projects, the center will also attract students to CSE fields. UTA and UTD have a strong record in training students and have ongoing NSF projects, e.g., to identify software errors, analysis of facial expressions to identify arthritic pain, or efficient multimodal database searches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the Center for Assistive Technologies to Improve Human Performance (iPerform) is to create long term research partnerships that bring together academia, industry, research centers, government, and service organizations in order to solve problems and develop technologies to improve human performance, as it affects productivity, quality of life, and competitiveness. The vision behind iPerform is to develop a broad range of translational research and computer tools to be used as assistive technologies. Depending on the context, the center targets human conditions or human directed processes and recommends, designs, and implements appropriate assistive technologies.

The center has been able to recruit member entities of all sizes, from large to medium to small, including private companies and government supported agencies, and of diverse interests. Faculty researchers and their students have met regularly with industry representatives to define and select projects of interest to members and potential members, resulting in a significant number of exciting projects that were pursued as part of the center. The University of Texas at Dallas site closely collaborated with the lead site at the University of Texas at Arlington to make sure that members understand the importance of joint ownership of results developed within the center.

Among the most notable outcomes the UT Dallas site can count are (1) Addressed industry needs for assistive technologies for natural dialogue systems through speech processing, assistive robotics, and improved software processes for assistive technologies, (2) Constructed benchmarks on human intelligence tasks such as rating language proficiency and judging spoken sentiment, (3) A full-body virtual reality system prototype for training with personal protective equipment, (4) A domain-independent framework for reusing subtask simulations for training, practice, and assessment across multiple domains and (5) A computer and smart glasses based assistive system to recognize close friends and family based on facial features, that could be used for people with prosopagnosia (face blindness) or to facilitate interaction at conferences and other social events; a key feature of the system is that it does not retain facial images but an encoding of a set of features as numerical values, eliminating privacy issues.

Dissemination of outcomes has been done through advertising, participation and presentations at events including iPerform IAB meetings, UTD ECS School IAB meetings, DFW Tech Titans Tech Industry Series, and publications. A few other universities and centers were involved in the effort of making the center known at national scale. 

Involvement with project investigation and development has helped a significant number of students at all academic levels (undergraduate, graduate MS and graduate PhD) develop skills that are otherwise difficult to achieve in standard classroom teaching. It also created a good level of excitement among students for participation in discovery and creation of new computer based technologies.
